body:
A couple high-level comments:
- Please add an architectural and/or usage wiki(s) under gobblin-docs/
- Have a look at http://gobblin.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developer-guide/GobblinModules/ and move the code under gobblin-modules. You can add it to the standard and full "flavors".
@enjoyear Some documentation in gobblin-docs/ will be greatly appreciated. I'd like to include this in the highlights of our 0.9 release notes.

@chavdar Is the documentation about job configuration, talking about the meaning of each key? Or is it about the hierarchy of the code, talking about relationships among different classes and the responsibility of different classes?
@pcadabam Could you please review

Mostly user-facing: usage, configuration, etc. Dev is good too if you
expect other people to extend/contribute.

LGTM. I checked all the files and the changes look good ;)
Can you please add a short description of what the changes are that can guide me through doing the review?

WorkUnits are presently serialized using SerializationUtils.serializeState() which writes using an Hadoop FS object. TaskState is written using an FsStateStore.  Changes are to store both of these state types using StateStores that can be backed by a non-filesystem storage.

StateStores store data with a key of (root, storeName, tableName). The root may be a path prefix in file system and ZK state stores.  For DB state store it is a DB table. storeName is the next level of the hierarchy. tableName is the last level and what is traditionally the file name, such as work_unit_name.wu is used for this field.

WorkUnits are stored at appWorkdir/_workunits/<job_id>/<work_unit_id>.wu.
MultiWorkUnits are stored at  appWorkdir/_workunits/<job_id>/<work_unit_id>.mwu
TaskStates are stored at  appWorkdir/_taskstates/<job_id>/<task_id>.tst

The path used in the test GobblinHelixTaskTest was changed to conform to the format above.

Three StateStores are instantiated through GobblinClusterUtils.StateStores for storing and accessing these states.  The StateStore type comes from the configuration key 'state.store.type'.
The configuration of 'state.store.root.dir' and 'state.store.db.table' are set before creating each StateStore to configure the proper root directory and root table.

The ParallelRunner is used to serialize and deserialize in parallel. A method that accepts a Callable was added to allow submitting the StateStore serialization and deserialization tasks. This generic interface was required due to avoid a build dependency issue.

StateStore changes:
Changed the ZK state put calls to create with data atomically when the znode does not exist.
Added a getStateNames() method for listing. This is required by the TaskStateCollectorService to find data to read.
Added factory method to StateStore and refactored some code shared between the DatasetStateStore factory and StateStore factory.

As chance would have it, I'm reworking this to remove the GobblinCallable and GobblinRunnable in most circumstances for an ExecutorService and ScheduledExecutorService which automatically wraps Runnable and Callable.

--
Joel Baranick
jbaranick@gmail.com

@shirshanka @chavdar does someone have time to review this? I think we should consider removing the intermediate queue all together. It makes the logic complex and can lead to race conditions (e.g. #840). Unless others have seen concrete scenarios where it makes a performance difference? Last I remember I hadn't seen any such cases.

Please add the following to your build.gradle to avoid the JDK 7 build failing: 

    ext.requiresJavaVersion=JavaVersion.VERSION_1_8
